section_06.section_summary: Meissonier, a French painter, was a patriot who joined the National Guard during the siege of Paris and planned to commemorate the city's defense in a large painting. He was known for his realistic and detailed military scenes, which showcased his ability to capture the unique personalities and characteristics of his subjects. Meissonier's work was not without criticism, with some noting his lack of color and grace, but his attention to detail and commitment to accuracy were unparalleled. He was particularly fond of painting horses and was meticulous in his research, often using himself as a model and studying historical relics to ensure accuracy. Meissonier's dedication to his craft and his passion for historical detail earned him great respect and admiration, culminating in his appointment as president of the Exposition Universelle des Beaux-Arts in 1889.
